user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8 is: A function parameter should not be modified.
Note that the object referred to by a pointer parameter may be modified, but the pointer itself shall not be modified.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of UT_Stub_IsValueCompatible:
```c
bool UT_Stub_IsValueCompatible(const UT_RetvalConfigEntry_t *Rvc, const char *WantTypeName, UT_ValueGenre_t WantGenre)
{
    bool IsCompatible;

    /* If the type names were specified on both sides, and they match, then the value is compatible */
    if (Rvc->TypeName != NULL && WantTypeName != NULL)
    {
        IsCompatible = (strcmp(Rvc->TypeName, WantTypeName) == 0);
    }
    else
    {
        /* The types are not _directly_ assignable, but it could possibly be coerced */
        IsCompatible = false;
    }

    /*
     * As an alternative/fallback, if the value genre is known for both sides,
     * check if coercion is a possibility.  For example, this could apply if the
     * value was int32 on one side and int16 on the other.
     */
    if (!IsCompatible && Rvc->Genre != UT_ValueGenre_OPAQUE && Rvc->Genre == WantGenre)
    {
        /* Genre match - should be compatible, with a potential size adjustment */
        IsCompatible = true;
    }

    return IsCompatible;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function UT_Stub_IsValueCompatible:
typedef struct
{
    UT_ValueGenre_t Genre;
    int32           Counter;
    UT_RetvalBuf_t  Buf;
    size_t          ActualSz;
    const char *    TypeName;
} UT_RetvalConfigEntry_t
...
typedef enum UT_ValueGenre
{
    UT_ValueGenre_OPAQUE  = 0, /**< The nature of the value is opaque, reference is stored directly (NOT copied!) */
    UT_ValueGenre_INTEGER = 1, /**< The value is an integer and may be converted to integers of other sizes */
    UT_ValueGenre_FLOAT   = 2, /**< The value is a floating point and may be converted to floats of other sizes */
    UT_ValueGenre_POINTER = 3  /**< The value is a pointer and should only be used to fulfill a pointer return */
} UT_ValueGenre_t
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: No function parameter is modified in the provided code. The function only reads from the parameters: it dereferences Rvc to read fields (allowed; modifying the pointed-to object is permitted), compares pointers against NULL, calls strcmp using the pointer values (no modification), and compares the value-parameter WantGenre. There are no assignments to the parameter variables (no statements like Rvc = ..., WantTypeName = ..., or WantGenre = ...). The only assignment present is to the local variable IsCompatible. Additionally, Rvc is a pointer to const, preventing modification of the pointed-to object in this function. Therefore there are no fragments that violate MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8 in this code.
